Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Solving Matching Problems in Machine Learning with Non-commutative Harmonic Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The problem of matching representations of one set of objects, e.g., their images, to representations of another set of objects that achieves an optimal global measure of overlap (goodness of match) is ubiquitous in computer science, and remains a fundamental challenge in areas such as machine learning, computer vision, and computational biology. While some cases are solvable in polynomial time, a majority of those encountered in practice are computationally intractable - NP-hard. This research will exploit the fact that in many matching problems of interest the space to be optimized over has the (algebraic) structure of group, which allows one to leverage an entire spectrum of ideas from abstract algebra, including non-commutative harmonic analysis and fast Fourier transforms on groups. In addition to yielding efficient optimization schemes in several important cases, this algebraic approach has the potential to serve as a basis for developing novel matching algorithms and suggest new approaches for certain classes of combinatorial optimization problems.

The proposed research has four main goals: to design faster general purpose harmonic analysis-based quadratic assignment problem (QAP) solvers and apply these to alignment and matching problems; to develop "tailored" QAP solution methods by coupling them to a learning component, which leverages training data to solve subsequent QAP instances much more efficiently; to design multiresolution analysis-based algorithms which yield global solutions to multi-object tracking and matching problems; and, to implement a flexible open-source library which offers a wide variety of harmonic analysis functionality (with support for wavelet and other transforms) to encourage experimentation on a broad class of inference and optimization problems. This project will yield a powerful set of algorithms and open-source software that can be used by researcher in areas of machine learning, computer vision, and optimization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Solving Matching Problems in Machine Learning with Non-commutative Harmonic Analysis (1320755)

 

 

Intellectual Merits: This collaborative project between Singh (UW-Madison) and Kondor (U of Chicago) explored the intersection between algebraic methods and various problems in AI arising from machine vision anddata analysis. The PIs and their students designed novel and efficient algorithms for applications ranging from facilitating 3D reconstruction of tourist locations from web images, matching images of the same scene to each other and interpretinghierarchy in features learned by deep networks to utilizing the mathematical theory of Fourier analysis on the symmetric group (permutations) to identify patterns in longitudinal and cross-sectional data acquired from individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD). These results were disseminated in the form of scientific publications at mainstream venues in machine learning, medical image analysis and computer vision, and provided as well-documented and easy to use software toolboxes to the scientific community. Various other research groups have already written follow-up papers building and extending upon the ideas derived as part of this project, which indicates that the results of this research have been appreciated by researchers. The project has also nourished a collaboration between the PIs with complementary strengths, at an early stage of their careers which will continue into the future. 


Broad Impacts: Other than immediate applications to data science, machine learning and computer vision, results from this project have direct use in the analysis of data obtained from individuals at risk for neurodegenerative diseases. Therefore, the potential impact of the project is broad reaching. The project also supported the training of multiple graduate students and undergraduate researchers who have since been accepted to prestigious graduate schools. Therefore, the project had a tangible effect on training/mentoring with significant outcomes.
